discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Phase A: Architecture Vision: Sets the overall direction and creates a preliminary roadmap, which is very high-level and conceptual.
Phase E: Opportunities and Solutions: Develops the initial complete version of the roadmap, including detailed work packages, timelines, and interdependencies, to move from the Baseline to Target Architectures.

Selected Answer: B
13.1 Objectives

The objectives of Phase E are to:

Generate the initial complete version of the Architecture Roadmap

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/arch/chap13.html

Correct Answer 

12.1 Objectives
The objectives of Phase E are to:

Generate the initial complete version of the Architecture Roadmap, based upon the gap analysis and candidate Architecture Roadmap components from Phases B, C, and D
Determine whether an incremental approach is required, and if so identify Transition Architectures that will deliver continuous business value
Define the overall solution building blocks to finalize the Target Architecture based on the Architecture Building Blocks (ABBs)

questions.question_text: What ADM Phase generates the initial complete version of the Architecture Roadmap?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
This is defined in Part IV, Chapter 30: Architecture Deliverables, Section 30.4, in the TOGAF 9.2 standard.

Selected Answer: E
33.1 Overview

artifact is an architectural work product that describes an aspect of the architecture. Artifacts are generally classified as catalogs (lists of things), matrices (showing relationships between things), and diagrams (pictures of things). Examples include a requirements catalog, business interaction matrix, and a use-case diagram. An architectural deliverable may contain many artifacts and artifacts will form the content of the Architecture Repository.

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/arch/chap33.html

Correct Answer 


An artifact is an architectural work product that describes an aspect of the architecture
Artifacts are generally classified as catalogs (lists of things), matrices (showing relationships between things), and diagrams (pictures of things). Examples include a requirements catalog, business interaction matrix, and a use-case diagram. An architectural deliverable may contain many artifacts and artifacts will form the content of the Architecture Repository.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does the TOGAF standard classify as catalogs, matrices and diagrams?
Which of the following best describes the TOGAF Architecture Development Method?

choices.C: A method for managing architecture requirements
choices.B: A method for developing an organization-specific architecture
choices.D: A method for classifying architectures and solutions
choices.E: A method for creating an Architecture Repository
choices.A: A method for controlling change at an enterprise-wide level

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
This is described in Part II, Chapter 5: Introduction to the ADM, in the TOGAF 9.2 standard.

Selected Answer: B
35.5 The Enterprise Continuum and the ADM

The TOGAF ADM describes the process of developing an enterprise-specific architecture and an enterprise-specific solution(s) which conform to that architecture by adopting and adapting (where appropriate) generic architectures and solutions (left to right in the continuum classification).

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap35.html

Selected Answer: B
B. A method for developing an organization-specific architecture

Correct Answer 

PART II
(Architecture Development Method) This part is the core of the TOGAF framework. It describes the TOGAF Architecture Development Method (ADM) - a step-by-step approach to developing an Enterprise Architecture

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the Reference Library within the Architecture Repository?

choices.D: A library of specifications to which architectures must conform
choices.A: Guidelines and templates used to create new architectures
choices.B: Processes to support governance of the Architecture Repository
choices.E: A record of the governance activity across the enterprise
choices.C: A description of the organization specific architecture framework and method

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This is described in Part V, Chapter 37: Architecture Repository, Section 37.2, in the TOGAF 9.2 standard.

Selected Answer: A
41.1 Overview
At a high level, six classes of architectural information are expected to be held within an Architecture Repository:

Reference Library provides guidelines, templates, patterns, and other forms of reference material that can be leveraged in order to accelerate the creation of new architectures for the enterprise.

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf91-doc/arch/chap41.html#:~:text=The%20Reference%20Library%20provides%20guidelines,governance%20activity%20across%20the%20enterprise.

Correct Answer 

37.1 Overview
The Reference Library provides guidelines, templates, patterns, and other forms of reference material that can be leveraged in order to accelerate the creation of new architectures for the enterprise

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the representation of a related set of concerns?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This is defined in Part I, Chapter 3: Definitions, Section 3.17, in the TOGAF 9.2 standard.

Selected Answer: A
14                  Stakeholders, Architecture Views, and Viewpoints

14.3             Architecture Views and Viewpoints

In general, a view is defined as a part of an Architecture Description that addresses a set of related concerns and is tailored for specific stakeholders.

https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/archimate3-doc/chap14.html
